Causal Accounts of Perception
3. Causal Accounts of Perception

Perception was, throughout the Middle Ages, a contentious topic, and
it was also a topic in which the answers to strictly causal
questions could influence philosophical positions in other areas (for
example, on whether certain knowledge of external entities was
attainable). The “traditional” view, dating back to Roger
Bacon in the mid-thirteenth century, was that physical objects were
known because they caused a succession of likenesses, or
species, first in the medium between the object and the perceiver,
then in the senses, and finally in the intellect, of the perceiver (Tachau
1988, pp. 3ff., Normore 2010, pp. 255f.).  This position was attacked by
thinkers such as Henry of Ghent, Peter Olivi,  and Duns Scotus. Interestingly,
many of these criticisms tend towards a relational account of perception, in
which – although species still play a role – the role that they play
is to be a means by which we know things, and in which the species
themselves are not known directly but only by reflection. (Tachau 1988, p. 66}.
(Panaccio 2010, pp. 242f., Normore 2010, pp. 255f.)

Ockham then radicalised these critiques by denying that there are any
such species at all: perception and other phenomena which
were usually explained by species – the sun heating or
illuminating physical objects, for example – were now explained by
action at a distance (Tachau 1988, pp. 130ff., Stump 1999). There was
a similar debate about the causal mechanisms behind memory, where,
again, Ockham denied a species-based account; however, in the
case of memory, he replaced species not with action at a distance but
with habits (Wolter and Adams 1993).

There was a similar late medieval debate on intentionality,
that is, the relation
between mental states and their objects. It is no surprise, given Ockham’s
arguments about species, that he took an externalist line on these,
too: he poses the question by asking whether, if an angel saw the contents of
my mind when I was thinking about some singular object, could the angel
(supposing that it did not know about anything external to my mind) tell which
object I was thinking about? Ockham answered no: and this thought experiment
seems to show that my mental state (i.e.\ my thinking of this particular
object) is not determined by the contents of my mind alone (Panaccio 2010, pp.
242f., William of Ockham 1981, pp. 378f.). This is clearly some sort
	of externalist position, but describing this position exactly has proved
to be surprisingly difficult (Panaccio 2010, Normore 2010, Brower-Toland 2007).
Correspondingly although many medieval thinkers were sympathetic to arguments
of this sort, the details of the positions they adopted were by no means
uniform. For example, followers of Scotus, such as Francis of Meyronnes, held
positions on intentionality which were intricate, were relational in some
sense, but were not straightforwardly externalist (Cesalli 2010). Debate on 
these issues continues into our era, and has invited comparison with, for
example, Sellars (1960): Sellars’ position, although interesting, does
not seem (as he claims) to reproduce Aquinas’ position on 
intentionality (King 2010). This only shows that there are a very large
number of different accounts of intentionality, and that the
medievals, even though they were surprisingly inventive in discovering them,
did not manage to discover all of them. 


Ockham denies species not on the basis of empirical evidence, or on
the basis of epistemological arguments, but purely and simply on the
basis of his razor: if we deny species, then we can give an
account of the phenomena which uses fewer entities, because
species are entities. Although this position of Ockham’s did
not have much influence on his contemporaries or followers – it is,
after all, extremely implausible – it is a good example of how causal
reasoning is affected by tacit ontological assumptions: the fact that
species were seen as entities and the fact that Ockham had a
programme of reducing the number of entities, led to an account of
perception which tried to do away with species. On the other
hand, action at a distance was, despite its implausibility, entirely
unaffected by Ockham’s critique. And, similarly, Ockham’s account was
not noticeably simpler than the accounts it criticised, which
shows how far Ockham’s own razor was from the principles of simplicity
and the like, which are usually considered to be its modern
equivalents.

One should note that, although Ockham was very innovative, and altered the
landscape of medieval thought quite decisively, there were very few, if any,
people who adopted his position without modification: he produced a large
number of interesting arguments, but, on the basis of these arguments, he
adopted positions which many of his contemporaries were not convinced by (Rode
2016, Courtenay 2008). So, although his arguments forced a reexamination of
many philosophical and theological doctrines, the thinkers influenced by him
took up a broad spectrum of positions, depending on which of his doctrines they
assented to and which of them they rejected. Walter Chatton, for example,
denied Ockham’s position on intuitive cognition – namely, that when
we know singulars we do so by a separate intellectual faculty distinct from
sense perception – in favour of a position that saw intuitive and sensory 
cognition as very much interrelated, and this, in turn, followed from a rejection
of Ockham’s position that the sensitive and intellectual souls were distinct 
(Schierbaum 2016).
